Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: I was deep into debugging a stubborn UI glitch when my phone buzzed. The issue wasn’t critical—users could refresh and move on—but QA was pressing for a fix before the next release. I glanced at the clock, calculating how long it might take to patch the code and run tests. Then another message came through, this one from the synagogue president: a beloved congregant had passed away, and the family needed me to officiate the funeral as soon as possible. My heart clenched. I knew how much comfort my presence and words could bring in their grief. But my team was counting on me, too; the release schedule was tight, and I’d already promised to handle this bug. I stared at my screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in—one demanding my technical focus, the other my spiritual presence. I could almost hear the voices: my manager’s urgency, the mourners’ need. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between duty and compassion, as I tried to decide which call to answer first.
